./.title: Introduction
./.body:
Introduction
Lowcal is essentially a wrapper around a set of
Docker Compose configurations that
make it easy to run a local/offline development environment for Docker.
It's an ideal choice for those that don't wish to run a full container
management or orchestration platform on their workstation. Lowcal has
been tested with Docker for Mac and
Docker Toolbox on
MacOS.
Requirements

Bash (bash)
Make (make)
Docker (docker)
Docker Compose (docker-compose)

pro_tips.html.title: Pro Tips
pro_tips.html.body:
Pro Tips
Due to
I/O performance issues with Docker for Mac,
you may have the best experience using Docker Machine with Parallels
Desktop Pro/Business and
the
corresponding Docker Machine driver.
Lowcal stands on the shoulders of giants. This is a tool for
convenience, and it should not be used to substitute knowledge of how to
use Docker, Docker Compose, or any of the related tools.

core_services.html.title: Core Services
core_services.html.body:
Core Services
Lowcal provides the following core services that are essential to its
operation:

Dnsmasq enables
DNS lookups for lowcal.dev and your own custom domain.
Consul is used for service discovery. When
you register a service via the
Consul Agent HTTP API, it
will automatically get picked up by traefik.
Traefik is a reverse proxy (and load
balancer). It "listens" to Docker and Consul, automatically updating
its configuration when you start a new Docker container, or register a
service with the Consul Agent.
cAdvisor provides a web UI
for analyzing the resource usage and performance characteristics of
running containers.

usage/.title: Usage
usage/.body:
Usage
Make sure you don't have any other containers exposing or local
services running on ports 80 or 443.
Traefik Port Overrides (optional)
If you must run Traefik on different ports, export the following
environment variables with the ports of your choice:
export TRAEFIK_HTTP_PORT=8880
export TRAEFIK_HTTPS_PORT=8843

Installation

Clone this repository
Run cd lowcal && make install
On MacOS, you'll be asked for your password


Optional: add lowcal to your $PATH. Edit your .bash_profile,
.bashrc, or .zshrc accordingly.

Help

./lowcal help
(make help)

Web UIs

Consul: http://consul.lowcal.dev
Traefik: http://traefik.lowcal.dev
cAdvisor: http://cadvisor.lowcal.dev

Removal

Run make clean
On MacOS, you'll be asked for your password

usage/configuration.html.title: Configuration
usage/configuration.html.body:
Configuration
Environment Variables
Lowcal uses environment variables exclusively for all configuration
parameters, many of which are passed directly to the underlying
containers.
For details, explore the docker-compose.yml at
the root of this repository, and the .yml files for each included
service in services/*.
Custom Domain
You can configure Lowcal to use your own domain:
export CUSTOM_DOMAIN="example.com"

If you would like to use HTTPS, you may choose one of the following
options:
HTTPS with Let's Encrypt
Internet connection required
Example configuration:
export TRAEFIK_ACME=true
#export TRAEFIK_ACME_STAGING=true
export TRAEFIK_ACME_LOGGING=true
export TRAEFIK_ACME_DNSPROVIDER=route53
export TRAEFIK_ACME_EMAIL=you@example.com
export TRAEFIK_ACME_ONDEMAND=false
export TRAEFIK_ACME_ONHOSTRULE=true

export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
export AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX
export AWS_REGION=us-east-1

Refer to
Traefik's documentation
for more information.
HTTPS with Static (or self-signed) Certificates
Works offline

Copy your certificate and key files to core/traefik/certs.
Set the following environment variables, replacing the values with
the appropriate file names:
export TRAEFIK_TLS_CERTFILE=example.crt
export TRAEFIK_TLS_KEYFILE=example.key



Docker Compose Projects
If your project uses docker-compose, here's an example
docker-compose.yml:
version: '2'
services:
  app:
    build: .
    environment:
      - TERM=xterm
    labels:
      - "traefik.backend=app"
      - "traefik.port=9000"
      - "traefik.frontend.rule=Host:app.example.com"
      - "traefik.frontend.entryPoints=http" # add ',https' for HTTPS support
      - "traefik.docker.network=lowcal"
      - "traefik.tags=lowcal"
    ports:
      - "9000:9000"
    volumes:
      - .:/app

networks:
  default:
    external:
      name: lowcal


You'll need to specify all the traefik.* labels for your web
service, customizing the backend, port, and frontend labels
accordingly.
Then copy/paste the networks block to the bottom of your
docker-compose.yml.

usage/supporting_services/.title: Supporting Services
usage/supporting_services/.body:
Supporting Services
For your convenience, Lowcal includes a handful of docker-compose
configurations for commonly used databases, DevOps tools, etc:
MySQL
Environment Variables (with defaults)
export MYSQL_VERSION=5
export MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD="abc123"
export MYSQL_DATABASE="lowcal"
export MYSQL_PORT=3306 # exposed to Docker host

LocalStack
Local AWS cloud stack
ssh-agent

Run: ./lowcal ssh-agent:up
Add your key: ./lowcal ssh-agent:add , where  is located in ~/.ssh/.

Service Management

Run ./lowcal services:list to get a list of the included services.
Run ./lowcal (service):help to get help for a particular service.
